prior_works.title: The reduction of a graph to a canonical form and an algebra which appears in the theory of graphs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: d-DRFWL(2) explicitly builds on the Folklore 2-WL procedure that colors ordered node pairs and passes messages between them, restricting it by distance to gain efficiency while retaining its substructure sensitivity.

prior_works.title: How Powerful are Graph Neural Networks?
prior_works.authors: Keyulu Xu, Weihua Hu, Jure Leskovec, Stefanie Jegelka
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By establishing that standard MPNNs are at most as powerful as 1-WL and cannot reliably count many cycles, this work motivates moving to pairwise/WL(2)-level mechanisms that d-DRFWL(2) operationalizes efficiently.

prior_works.title: Weisfeiler and Leman Go Neural: Higher-Order Graph Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Christopher Morris, Martin Ritzert, Matthias Fey, William L. Hamilton, Jan E. Lenssen, Gaurav Rattan, Martin Grohe
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces neural realizations of k-WL (including pairwise 2-WL/folklore variants), showing their superior substructure counting power but high O(n^k) cost—precisely the power source that d-DRFWL(2) keeps while curbing cost via distance restriction.

prior_works.title: Provably Powerful Graph Networks
prior_works.authors: Haggai Maron, Heli Ben-Hamu, Haggai Serviansky, Yaron Lipman
prior_works.role: Higher-order, provably powerful but costly architectures
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows tensor-based higher-order GNNs can count motifs (e.g., triangles) yet incur steep computational overhead, underscoring the need for practical designs like distance-restricted 2-WL that preserve counting power with lower complexity.

prior_works.title: Link Prediction Based on Graph Neural Networks (SEAL)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Pioneers the bag-of-subgraphs paradigm by extracting enclosing subgraphs around node pairs; d-DRFWL(2) targets similar subgraph-awareness and cycle sensitivity but avoids SEAL’s heavy subgraph extraction and preprocessing.

prior_works.title: Graph Substructure Networks (GSN)
prior_works.authors: Giorgos Bouritsas, Fabrizio Frasca, Stefanos Zafeiriou, Michael M. Bronstein
prior_works.role: Motif-aware GNNs with provable counting via precomputed features
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates that injecting substructure/motif signals yields provable cycle counting but relies on precomputing counts; d-DRFWL(2) attains provable cycle counting intrinsically through pairwise WL dynamics without motif preprocessing.

prior_works.title: Relational Pooling for Graph Representations
prior_works.authors: Ryan L. Murphy, Balasubramaniam Srinivasan, Vikas K. Garg, Bruno Ribeiro
prior_works.role: Maximally expressive but computationally expensive baseline
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides permutation-averaging to surpass WL limits (including cycle counting) at prohibitive cost, highlighting the expressivity–efficiency trade-off that d-DRFWL(2) addresses with local, distance-restricted pairwise message passing.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—d-DRFWL(2), a distance-restricted Folklore 2-WL GNN that provably counts cycles while remaining efficient—sits at the intersection of WL theory, higher-order GNN design, and subgraph-centric expressivity. Weisfeiler and Leman’s original color refinement underpins the idea of coloring ordered node pairs and propagating information among them, the very mechanics that give 2-WL its ability to discern and count cyclic structures. Xu et al. formalized the expressive ceiling of standard MPNNs via 1-WL equivalence, crystallizing the need to go beyond neighborhood aggregation to capture cycles. Morris et al. then mapped k-WL (including pairwise 2-WL/folklore) into neural architectures, showing their superior substructure-counting power but also their quadratic or worse scaling. In parallel, Maron et al. demonstrated that higher-order equivariant networks can provably count motifs like triangles, yet at significant computational cost, reinforcing the need for practical approximations. Subgraph methods such as SEAL and GSN validated that injecting subgraph/motif context enables cycle counting in practice, but they rely on heavy preprocessing—extracting bags of subgraphs or precomputing motif counts. Relational Pooling further illustrates that maximal expressivity is achievable but computationally prohibitive. d-DRFWL(2) synthesizes these strands: it retains the 2-WL pairwise expressive advantages responsible for cycle counting while sidestepping both higher-order tensor blow-ups and subgraph/motif preprocessing by restricting pairwise message passing to pairs within a bounded graph distance, delivering a provably cycle-counting yet scalable GNN.
